title: Introduction to Learning Sciences
description: This course provides an overview of basic concepts and theories of learning sciences.First, concepts and theories of cognitive psychology related to learning are introduced, including but not limited to attention, language processing, working memory, long-term memory, meaningful learning, constructivism, knowledge representation, memory processes of encoding, retrieval, and forgetting.Second, evidence-based instructional strategies and principles based on research in learning sciences are discussed, such as attention/memory training, flipped classroom, speed reading, learning styles, game-based learning, feedback, worked examples, spacing and interleaving, influence of mood and anxiety, metacognition and self-regulation, and practice testing.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:1.  demonstrate an understanding of psychological theories of learning sciences and their relationship with instructional practices2.  describe, analyze, and evaluate evidence-based instructional strategies and/or principles based on research in learning sciences3.  apply effective evidence-based instructional strategies to foster students' learning (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.) 完成本科後，學生應該能夠：1.  展示對學習科學的心理學理論及其與教學實踐的關係的理解2.  描述、分析和評估基於學習科學的研究和以實證為基礎的教學策略和原則3.  應用有效而以實證為基礎的教學策略來促進學生的學習 （個別科目教師可在必要時更新學習成果。）
syllabus: Week 1: Course introduction; Basic concepts of learning sciences Week 2: Cognitive theories of learning sciencesWeek 3: Attention, memory, and cognitive trainingWeek 4: Language processing, text comprehension, and speed readingWeek 5: Desirable difficulty and feedbackWeek 6: Worked examples and analogical reasoningWeek 7: Emotion, anxiety, and cognitionWeek 8: Cognitive load, multimedia, and game-based learningWeek 9: Metacognition, self-regulated learning, and flipped classroomWeek 10: Spacing and InterleavingWeek 11: Practice testingWeek 12: Group presentationWeek 13: Wrap up (Individual course teachers may update the course syllabus as and whenever necessary.)

title: Learning Design in New and Emerging Educational Contexts
description: This course aims to discuss what, why and how learning design elements can/ should be incorporated in learning environments to support effective learning in new and emerging educational contexts. Particularly, the focus of the course will be on examining the integration of learning design principles and approaches in accordance with the educational goals of the twenty-first century.
outcome: By the end of the course, participants will:1.  understand the rationales and underpinning theories behind various learning design principles;2.  employ appropriate learning design approaches to supporting multiple ways of learning in face-to-face and online settings;3.  evaluate strengths and weaknesses of various learning design principles and approaches with respect to various educational contexts;4.  gain pedagogical knowledge and technological skills related to learning design in new and emerging educational contexts.
syllabus: -  Principles of learning design-  Instructional analysis-  Technological pedagogical context knowledge-  Inquiry-based learning-  Flipped learning- Computer-supported collaborative learning- Project-based learning

components:

Web-enhanced Teaching
Workshop
description: Analysis of learner data provides valuable insight into learning processes to understand and optimize learning environments. This enables universities, schools, and training organizations to improve the quality and overall efficiency of learning. This course will provide an introduction to analytics in learning and how it is being deployed in various contexts in education, including to inform educators, and to promote scientific discovery. Students will explore the logic of analytics, the basics of cleaning and using educational data, context analysis, and predictive models. This course will also discuss tools and analytics methods that educators need, and how to protect learner privacy and other rights.

description: Design thinking as scientific inquiry is an innovative approach for developing user-centered innovative solutions in business and society. This course will discuss design thinking principles such as user participation, problem framing, prototype making, experimentation and evaluation, visualization and diversity, which are essential skills for management and innovation. It will also discuss how design thinking drives innovation and solves some of the most global and local complex problems, for example, develop new product/service development, and address strategic, operational, organizational and social issues. Upon completion, students are able to apply design thinking to their own situations and organizations, and plan for how to embed this type of thinking to drive innovation.
outcome: On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1.  understand design thinking and scientific inquiry, their phases and operation, and their application in practice;2.  understand how design thinking principles solve different problems in different contexts;3.  recognize the value of design thinking and scientific inquiry to organizations, economies and society;4.  apply the design thinking as scientific inquiry to create and manage projects.
syllabus: There are five topics in this course-  Introduction to design thinking and scientific inquiry-  General approaches to design thinking-  Design thinking as scientific inquire approaches-  Design thinking techniques-  The impact of design thinking-  Implementations of design thinking

description: A digital citizen is a person who develops the skills, literacy, competence to safely and effectively use the internet and digital technologies. It plays a powerful role in facilitating people learn, connect, engage with their community, and create more promising futures. This course will discuss competencies of digital citizenship such as digital literacy, artificial intelligence literacy, media literacy, and computational thinking. Students will design, develop, and evaluate a digital citizenship program is used by individuals, nonprofits, schools, and governments all over the world.
outcome: On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1. describe and explain different literacies needed for digital citizens;2. understand the importance of the digital citizenships competencies in different context;3. design, develop and evaluate a digital citizenship education program.
syllabus: There are seven topics in this course:-Introduction to digital citizenship-Digital literacy-Media literacy-Artificial intelligence-Computational thinking skills-Privacy and ethical issue-Digital citizenship education project design and development

title: Leading Innovations in Organizations in the Era of Globalization
description: This course aims to provide a broad understanding of the importance of innovation to organizations and the role of innovative leadership in the contemporary society. Various types of innovation and models of organizations and leadership will be explored to elucidate their inter-relationships. Students will have an opportunity to examine the characteristics of innovative learning organizations with real-life examples including the organizational structure, culture and leadership strategies for organizational change. Key processes of organizational learning, teamwork, strategic development and knowledge management will be analyzed in specific contexts. Through reviewing a range of literature and applying it to multiple scenarios, students are encouraged to integrate theory with practice and develop their leadership capacity for driving innovation in different organizational settings.

description: This course is a form of experiential learning, which provides opportunities for students to put the knowledge and skills they have learned from the programme into practice via engaging in a real-life career in the learning design and technology industry. Areas of industry attachment include technology companies, e-learning service providers, training and development companies, universities, schools, libraries and governmental organizations. Students are expected to carry out their responsibilities as if they are full-time employees of the industry they are attached to. Evaluation of student performance will be based on multiple sources, such as participation in tutorials, internship performance, the internship report, and evaluation by the industry supervisor.
outcome: Upon the completion of the course, students will be able to:-  Learn from other professionals in the field;-  Develop future career options / opportunities;-  Develop positive attitude and responsibility, and strong work ethics;-  Develop problem solving skills;-  Develop beneficial links with the Learning Design and Technology Industry;-  Demonstrate ability in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of a work task independently.

title: Educational Design Research (Research Method)
description: This course aims to provide an overview on various research methods (qualitative, quantitative and mixed methods) used in educational research and prepare students to conduct their own research project. The course will go through the steps in designing research topic and questions, searching and reviewing relevant literature, formulating research hypotheses, identifying suitable research tools and sampling methods, analyzing and interpreting research findings and writing up research reports with students. Students will also learn the principles of research ethics and procedures in obtaining ethics clearance at CUHK.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:1.  demonstrate an understanding of the basic principles of research methods in the area of educational design and technology2.  conduct literature search and review, identify research gaps for a selected research topic and formulate relevant hypotheses3.  determine the suitable research tools and data collection methods to address the proposed research questions;4.  analyze and interpret collected data and prepare a structured research report5.  explain the principles of research ethics and complete the CUHK ethics clearance procedures (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)  完成本科後，學生應該能夠：1. 展示對教育設計和技術領域研究方法的基本原理的理解2.  進行文獻檢索和評論，辨認研究課題中的研究缺口並提出相關假設3.  確定合適的研究工具和數據收集方法來解決擬議的研究問題4.  分析和解釋數據並將之撰寫成研究報告5.  解釋研究倫理原則並完成中大倫理審查程序  （個別科目教師可在必要時更新學習成果。）

title: Educational Innovation and Society: A Comparative Perspective
description: Educational innovation can be found in processes, services, programmes and partnerships. Educational innovation improves teaching and learning, enhances wellbeing, ensures successful transitions and pathways, as well as alleviates inequity. This course will start with an introduction on the role of education in economic development followed by discussion on various forms of educational innovation in schooling systems including alternative schools. Case studies on innovative educational practice in different countries will be examined. Students will be asked to identify educational challenges that learners and teachers are grappling with. Guest lectures are offered by leaders of local or international social enterprises and foundations that practice and support educational innovations. Students will be invited to brainstorm and join social enterprises’ efforts to provide sustainable strategies to tackle development issues especially to that of educational equality. Evaluation on how educational innovations promote student learning will also be explored. At the end of the course, students will develop a proposal that advances current educational practices in our society reflecting community needs and addressing the social inequality and poverty issues.

title: Education, Technology and Human Development
description: This course provides an introductory survey of the links between education, technological advancement and human development in the globe. While digital and technological innovation accelerates economic growth and plays a critical role for reducing poverty, it also trigger social inequality issues. Further, technological changes (such as computerization, artificial intelligence, etc.) will fundamentally alter the nature of professions and of high skilled jobs generally. The course starts with an overview of the current educational attainment and schooling investments across the world. This is followed by exploring the demand for human capital and educational investments aligned with economic development, public financing of education. Students will also be able to examine interactions between education, technology and development from social and economic perspectives on other issues, including compulsory education reform, manpower planning and curriculum reform, automation and its impact on jobs and labor market, gender gap in schooling and STEM subjects, welfare policy reforms and its impact on children.

title: Instructional Design for Students with SEN in Technology-Supported Learning Environments
requirements: Not for students who have taken EDUC4340.
description: This course aims to provide students with fundamental knowledge of selected areas of special needs (learning disabilities, autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit / hyperactivity disorder, emotional and behavioral disorder, and giftedness) and help them to understand possible learning difficulties children with these special needs would encounter. For each kind of special need, students will learn its characteristics, causes, and provision of special education in Hong Kong. Besides, this course will also prepare students for designing effective solutions using technology for children with learning, literacy, and cognitive challenges.
outcome: At the end of the semester, students should be able to:1.  describe the characteristics of various types of special-needs children and the difficulties they encounter2.  have an understanding of provision of special education in Hong Kong3.  develop relevant intervention strategies using technology to facilitate student development and enhance learning in primary school years 在學期結束時，學生應該能夠：1.  了解各類特需兒童的特點和遇到的困難2.  了解香港提供特殊教育3.  使用科技發展相關的干預策略，以促進學生的發展和加強小學階段的學習

description: This is a two-semester course for final year students of the programme. Under the guidance of project supervisors, students are required to complete an individual project pertaining to the applications of learning, design, and technology in education, workplace, or other organizational settings. They should draw on theoretically-informed and empirically-validated learning design frameworks to design innovative and authentic technology-enriched learning experiences for the participants so that the curricular goals are attained. They should propose a project in the field of Learning Design and Technology and execute that project from analysis to evaluation.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:1.  identify a critical issue that merits further investigation in the field of Learning Design and Technology;2.  integrate the content, knowledge, and skills from prior learning to address the issue concerned;3.  show their research, analytical, and higher order thinking skills during the research process; and4.  generate new understanding from their project findings to help develop their future profession.
syllabus: This is an independent study course. Students are expected to conduct a study on their own that leads to the writing of a research report under the guidance of project supervisors. They should meet their supervisors for reporting the project progress and seeking advice regularly. They are also encouraged to make appointments with their supervisors to discuss any problems encountered during each phase of their studies if needed.

description: Analysis of learner data provides valuable insight into learning processes to understand and optimize learning environments. This enables universities, schools, and training organizations to improve the quality and overall efficiency of learning. This course will provide an introduction to analytics in learning and how it is being deployed in various contexts in education, including to inform educators, and to promote scientific discovery. Students will explore the logic of analytics, the basics of cleaning and using educational data, context analysis, and predictive models. This course will also discuss tools and analytics methods that educators need, and how to protect learner privacy and other rights.

description: Design thinking as scientific inquiry is an innovative approach for developing user-centered innovative solutions in business and society. This course will discuss design thinking principles such as user participation, problem framing, prototype making, experimentation and evaluation, visualization and diversity, which are essential skills for management and innovation. It will also discuss how design thinking drives innovation and solves some of the most global and local complex problems, for example, develop new product/service development, and address strategic, operational, organizational and social issues. Upon completion, students are able to apply design thinking to their own situations and organizations, and plan for how to embed this type of thinking to drive innovation.

description: This course is a form of experiential learning, which provides opportunities for students to put the knowledge and skills they have learned from the programme into practice via engaging in a real-life career in the learning design and technology industry. Areas of industry attachment include technology companies, e-learning service providers, training and development companies, universities, schools, libraries and governmental organizations. Students are expected to carry out their responsibilities as if they are full-time employees of the industry they are attached to. Evaluation of student performance will be based on multiple sources, such as participation in tutorials, internship performance, the internship report, and evaluation by the industry supervisor.
